G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Superior Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 231, § 1, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 when considering medical expenses, pain and suffering, and other damages reasonably expected to be proved at trial.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: The Superior Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 231, § 1, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 when considering medical expenses, pain and suffering, and other damages reasonably expected to be proved at trial.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the cause of action arose within Bristol County, namely at the Premises located at or associated with 45 Thatcher Street in Brockton, Massachusetts.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, a breach of that duty, causation, and resulting damages. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The Jupin opinion expressly states the elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law: duty, breach, causation, and damages. The court sets these elements out in general terms, not in a case-specific way, and cites a secondary source, making it clear that it is articulating the standard negligence framework that the proposition describes. Although it does not cite Glidden, the portion of Jupin cited directly supports the quoted negligence-elements proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “3. Negligence claim, a. Duty of care, generally. To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, a breach of that duty, causation, and resulting damages. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not set out the full four-element formulation of negligence (duty, breach, causation, and damages). Instead, it describes the plaintiffs’ burden more narrowly as proving a breach of the duty of reasonable care, actual loss, and causation, and explicitly notes that causation is an essential element. While consistent with the general Massachusetts rule, the case is not itself authority for the specific four-part articulation cited in the proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to J.S. arising from: (a) its status as the operator of the after‑school program that undertook to supervise and protect children in its care; and (b) its control over the Premises and the activities conducted thereon.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 50–51 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to J.S. arising from: (a) its status as the operator of the after‑school program that undertook to supervise and protect children in its care; and (b) its control over the Premises and the activities conducted thereon.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on proximate cause, not on whether the defendant college owed a duty of reasonable care arising from its role supervising students or controlling the premises. The justice explicitly agrees with the majority on all issues other than causation, and the quoted portion does not discuss the existence or scope of any duty. Thus, as used here, Mullins does not provide authority for the duty proposition stated.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "O’Connor, J. (dissenting). I agree with the opinion of the court except for its conclusion that the evidence warrants a finding that the defendants’ negligent acts or omissions proximately caused the plaintiff’s injury. ... In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor."

Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 75.raw_text: Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756 (1984)
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 75.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to J.S. arising from: (a) its status as the operator of the after‑school program that undertook to supervise and protect children in its care; and (b) its control over the Premises and the activities conducted thereon.
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 75.support_reasoning: The case does recognize that the town (through its police officers) owed a duty of reasonable care to members of the motoring public once officers encountered an intoxicated driver and failed to remove him from the road. However, the duty arises from statutory law enforcement responsibilities and the special relationship analysis regarding police conduct toward intoxicated motorists, not from the defendant’s status as an operator of an after‑school program or from premises‑liability/control of land. Because Irwin is about police duties to protect the motoring public, it does not support a proposition about duties of an after‑school program supervising children on its premises.
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 75.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that there is a special relationship between a police officer who negligently fails to remove an intoxicated motorist from the highway, and a member of the public who suffers injury as a result of that failure. The statutes which establish police responsibilities in such circumstances evidence a legislative intent to protect both intoxicated persons and other users of the highway. As to the most crucial factor — foreseeability — the calamitous consequences to the victims of accidents caused by drunken driving are all too predictable.” (392 Mass. at 761-62)

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant owed J.S. the duty to exercise the care that a reasonably prudent childcare and recreational facility would use under like circumstances in supervising children in its charge and in controlling activities in its gym so as to avoid subjecting them to unreasonable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: This excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion addressing the abandonment of the licensee/invitee distinction in premises liability and criticizing the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not concern, or set out, the specific duty of a childcare or recreational facility in supervising children or gym activities. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the particular standard of care stated in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.proposition: Defendant owed J.S. the duty to exercise the care that a reasonably prudent childcare and recreational facility would use under like circumstances in supervising children in its charge and in controlling activities in its gym so as to avoid subjecting them to unreasonable risks of harm.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.support_reasoning: The case concerns the duty a landowner owes to an adult trespasser and expressly holds that the only duty is to refrain from wilful, wanton, or reckless conduct. It does not discuss or impose a duty of reasonable care on a childcare or recreational facility in supervising children or controlling activities in a gym. The proposition relates to a specialized duty of care in a child‑supervision/recreational context, which this trespasser‑status premises‑liability case does not address and in fact is inconsistent with, as it rejects a general reasonable‑care duty to adult trespassers.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.relevant_excerpt: “The traditional rule in this Commonwealth is that a trespasser is entitled to no greater duty of care from one with a right of control over land (typically the landowner) than that he refrain from wilful, wanton or reckless disregard for the trespasser’s safety. Chronopoulos v. Gil Wyner Co., 334 Mass. 593, 596 (1956). Sweeny v. Old Colony & Newport R.R., 10 Allen 368, 372 (1865).”

Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to protect J.S., a foreseeable and clearly identifiable member of the class of persons entrusted to its care, from unreasonable physical harm caused by the conduct of other children when such harm was reasonably foreseeable and preventable through the exercise of reasonable supervision and control.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s duty to protect a foreseeable child in its care from harm by other children through reasonable supervision and control—a school or custodial-supervision type duty. Remy v. MacDonald addresses a completely different duty question: whether a pregnant woman owes a legal duty in negligence to her unborn child for her own conduct (here, negligent driving). The court ultimately holds that no such duty exists and does not discuss duties to protect children from other children or duties arising from custodial relationships, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide whether a pregnant woman owes a legal duty of care to her unborn child to refrain from negligent conduct that may result in physical harm to that child. If no such duty exists, a claim of negligence cannot be brought. … We conclude that there are inherent and important differences between a fetus, in utero, and a child already born, that permits a bright line to be drawn around the zone of potential tort liability of one who is still biologically joined to an injured plaintiff.”

Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 11\u2013.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to protect J.S., a foreseeable and clearly identifiable member of the class of persons entrusted to its care, from unreasonable physical harm caused by the conduct of other children when such harm was reasonably foreseeable and preventable through the exercise of reasonable supervision and control.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 11\u2013.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant owed a duty to protect a foreseeable and identifiable person (or class of persons) from unreasonable physical harm caused by other children when such harm was reasonably foreseeable and preventable through reasonable supervision. Wallace v. Wilson holds the opposite: it explicitly declines to impose a duty on a parent to supervise a teenage party to protect third persons from harm caused by intoxicated minors, even when the parent knows or should know alcohol will be consumed. The court affirms summary judgment because no such duty exists as a matter of law in these circumstances.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 11\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “We said, ‘We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available. The defendant’s conduct did not create a risk of injury to the plaintiff for which we are prepared to say the common law should provide a remedy.’ … We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here.”

McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.raw_text: McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1108, 1109 (1989) (Rule 1:28 decision)
McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: By undertaking to operate an after‑school program and advertising that children would be “supervised at all times in the gym,” Defendant assumed a duty to exercise reasonable care consistent with those representations, and Plaintiff reasonably relied upon that undertaking.
McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns parental liability for the intentional shooting committed by their 27‑year‑old son and whether he was emancipated; it does not involve any after‑school program, advertising of supervision, or an assumed duty based on such representations. The court’s analysis is limited to whether parents of an emancipated adult have a duty to supervise or control him and explicitly finds no such duty. Thus, the case neither addresses nor supports the proposition about assuming a duty by undertaking and advertising continuous supervision of children in a program setting.
McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.relevant_excerpt: “‘The fortuity of [Peter’s] living in [his parents’] home does not create a duty where none otherwise exists; nor does their status as parents, without more, impose on [them] the duty to supervise and control their emancipated adult son.’ Alioto v. Marnell, 402 Mass. 36, 39 (1988).”

Jupin, 447 Mass. at 148\u201349.proposition: Defendant breached its duty by failing to train, supervise, and monitor its staff to ensure that they would exercise reasonable care in supervising children and intervening to prevent foreseeable injuries from rough play. See Jupin, 447 Mass. at 148–49 (negligent failure to control and supervise foreseeable risks).

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s breaches of its duty of care directly and proximately caused J.S.’s injuries. See Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320–21 (2002) (causation where negligent conduct is substantial contributing factor).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The proposition claims Kent as authority that negligent conduct constitutes legal causation where it is a substantial contributing factor to the injury. Kent does discuss proximate cause, but it ultimately holds that the defendant’s alleged negligence was not the proximate cause because intervening federal INS actions were a superseding cause. The opinion does not adopt or highlight a ‘substantial contributing factor’ test; instead, it emphasizes foreseeability, policy limits on proximate cause, and superseding cause. Citing Kent as positive authority for causation being satisfied where negligence is a substantial contributing factor misstates the case’s holding and use of causation doctrine.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978). … [T]he INS action constituted a superseding cause of the harm that followed.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on any damages awarded for personal injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85, 85L.proposition: Plaintiff brings this action on behalf of his minor son, J.S., for J.S.’s pain and suffering, emotional distress, and all other compensable elements of damage, and also in his individual capacity for recovery of medical and related expenses incurred on behalf of his minor child.

Gage v. City of Westfield, 26 Mass. App..raw_text: Gage v. City of Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681, 694 (1988)
Gage v. City of Westfield, 26 Mass. App..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was not excused or justified by any contributory negligence on the part of J.S., who was a minor eight‑year‑old child and was entitled to a heightened degree of protection. See G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence); Gage v. City of Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681, 694 (1988).
Gage v. City of Westfield, 26 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The case does not involve an eight‑year‑old child, comparative negligence, or any discussion of a heightened duty of care owed to young minors. Instead, it concerns a sixteen‑year‑old and an eighteen‑year‑old and addresses municipal tort immunity, railroad statutory protections, and standards of recklessness versus negligence. The brief mention of comparative negligence in footnote 8 is hypothetical and directed to adult trespassers, not to minors entitled to special protection, so the opinion does not support the stated proposition.
Gage v. City of Westfield, 26 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “If liability for negligence were imposed on the railroad, in the circumstances, the presence of the youths on the tracks in violation of G. L. c. 160, § 218, would certainly raise an issue of comparative negligence. See Lane v. Meserve, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 659, 663 n.6 (1985).” (26 Mass. App. Ct. at 698 n.8).

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including allowable fees and expenses, pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and other applicable law;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
